The IWLS algorithm used to fit conditional logit models

Source: vignettes/fitting-mclogit.Rmd
fitting-mclogit.Rmd

The package â€œmclogitâ€ fits conditional logit models using a maximum likelihood estimator. It does this by maximizing the log-likelihood function using an iterative weighted least-squares (IWLS) algorithm, which follows the algorithm used by the glm.fit() function from the â€œstatsâ€ package of R (Nelder and Wedderburn 1972; McCullagh and Nelder 1989; R Core Team 2023).

If Ï€ij\pi_{ij} is the probability that individual ii chooses alternative jj from his/her choice set ğ’®i\mathcal{S}_i, where

Ï€ij=exp(Î·ij)âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’®iexp(Î·ik) \pi_{ij}=\frac{\exp(\eta_{ij})}{\sum_k{\in\mathcal{S}_i}\exp(\eta_{ik})}

and if yijy_{ij} is the dummy variable with equals 1 if individual ii chooses alternative jj and equals 0 otherwise, the log-likelihood function (given that the choices are identically independent distributed given Ï€ij\pi_{ij}) can be written as

â„“=âˆ‘i,jyijlnÏ€ij=âˆ‘i,jyijÎ·ijâˆ’âˆ‘iln(âˆ‘jexp(Î·ij)) \ell=\sum_{i,j}y_{ij}\ln\pi_{ij} =\sum_{i,j}y_{ij}\eta_{ij}-\sum_i\ln\left(\sum_j\exp(\eta_{ij})\right)

If the data are aggregated in the terms of counts such that nijn_{ij} is the number of individuals with the same choice set and the same choice probabilities Ï€ij\pi_{ij} that have chosen alternative jj, the log-likelihood is (given that the choices are identically independent distributed given Ï€ij\pi_{ij})

â„“=âˆ‘i,jnijlnÏ€ij=âˆ‘i,jnijÎ·ijâˆ’âˆ‘ini+ln(âˆ‘jexp(Î·ij)) \ell=\sum_{i,j}n_{ij}\ln\pi_{ij} =\sum_{i,j}n_{ij}\eta_{ij}-\sum_in_{i+}\ln\left(\sum_j\exp(\eta_{ij})\right)

where ni+=âˆ‘jâˆˆğ’®inijn_{i+}=\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}_i}n_{ij}.

If

Î·ij=Î±1x1ij+â‹¯+Î±rxrij=ğ±ijâ€²ğ›‚ \eta_{ij} = \alpha_1x_{1ij}+\cdots+\alpha_rx_{rij}=\boldsymbol{x}_{ij}'\boldsymbol{\alpha}

then the gradient of the log-likelihood with respect to the coefficient vector ğ›‚\boldsymbol{\alpha} is

âˆ‚â„“âˆ‚ğ›‚=âˆ‘i,jâˆ‚Î·ijâˆ‚ğ›‚âˆ‚â„“âˆ‚Î·ij=âˆ‘i,jğ±ij(nijâˆ’ni+Ï€ij)=âˆ‘i,jğ±ijni+(yijâˆ’Ï€ij)=ğ—â€²ğ(ğ²âˆ’ğ›‘) \frac{\partial\ell}{\partial\boldsymbol{\alpha}} = \sum_{i,j} \frac{\partial\eta_{ij}}{\partial\boldsymbol{\alpha}} \frac{\partial\ell}{\partial\eta_{ij}} = \sum_{i,j} \boldsymbol{x}_{ij} (n_{ij}-n_{i+}\pi_{ij}) = \sum_{i,j} \boldsymbol{x}_{ij} n_{i+} (y_{ij}-\pi_{ij}) = \boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{N}(\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{\pi})

and the Hessian is

âˆ‚2â„“âˆ‚ğ›‚âˆ‚ğ›‚â€²=âˆ‘i,jâˆ‚Î·ijâˆ‚ğ›‚âˆ‚Î·ijâˆ‚ğ›‚â€²âˆ‚â„“2âˆ‚Î·ij2=âˆ’âˆ‘i,j,kğ±ijni+(Î´jkâˆ’Ï€ijÏ€ik)ğ±ijâ€²=âˆ’ğ—â€²ğ–ğ— \frac{\partial^2\ell}{\partial\boldsymbol{\alpha}\partial\boldsymbol{\alpha}'} = \sum_{i,j} \frac{\partial\eta_{ij}}{\partial\boldsymbol{\alpha}} \frac{\partial\eta_{ij}}{\partial\boldsymbol{\alpha}'} \frac{\partial\ell^2}{\partial\eta_{ij}^2} = - \sum_{i,j,k} \boldsymbol{x}_{ij} n_{i+} (\delta_{jk}-\pi_{ij}\pi_{ik}) \boldsymbol{x}_{ij}' = - \boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{W}\boldsymbol{X}

Here yij=nij/ni+y_{ij}=n_{ij}/n_{i+}, while ğ\boldsymbol{N} is a diagonal matrix with diagonal elements ni+n_{i+}.

Newton-Raphson iterations then take the form

ğ›‚(s+1)=ğ›‚(s)âˆ’(âˆ‚2â„“âˆ‚ğ›‚âˆ‚ğ›‚â€²)âˆ’1âˆ‚â„“âˆ‚ğ›‚=ğ›‚(s)+(ğ—â€²ğ–ğ—)âˆ’1ğ—â€²ğ(ğ²âˆ’ğ›‘) \boldsymbol{\alpha}^{(s+1)} = \boldsymbol{\alpha}^{(s)} - \left( \frac{\partial^2\ell}{\partial\boldsymbol{\alpha}\partial\boldsymbol{\alpha}'} \right)^{-1} \frac{\partial\ell}{\partial\boldsymbol{\alpha}} = \boldsymbol{\alpha}^{(s)} + \left( \boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{W}\boldsymbol{X} \right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{N}(\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{\pi})

where ğ›‘\boldsymbol{\pi} and ğ–\boldsymbol{W} are evaluated at ğ›‚=ğ›‚(s)\boldsymbol{\alpha}=\boldsymbol{\alpha}^{(s)}.

Multiplying by ğ—â€²ğ–ğ—\boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{W}\boldsymbol{X} gives

ğ—â€²ğ–ğ—ğ›‚(s+1)=ğ—â€²ğ–ğ—ğ›‚(s)+ğ—â€²ğ(ğ²âˆ’ğ›‘)=ğ—â€²ğ–(ğ—ğ›‚(s)+ğ–âˆ’ğ(ğ²âˆ’ğ›‘))=ğ—â€²ğ–ğ²* \boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{W}\boldsymbol{X} \boldsymbol{\alpha}^{(s+1)} = \boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{W}\boldsymbol{X} \boldsymbol{\alpha}^{(s)} + \boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{N}(\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{\pi}) = \boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{W} \left(\boldsymbol{X}\boldsymbol{\alpha}^{(s)}+\boldsymbol{W}^-\boldsymbol{N}(\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{\pi})\right) = \boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{W}\boldsymbol{y}^*

where ğ–âˆ’\boldsymbol{W}^- is a generalized inverse of ğ–\boldsymbol{W} and ğ²*\boldsymbol{y}^* is a â€œworking response vectorâ€ with elements

yij*=ğ±ijâ€²ğ›‚(s)+yijâˆ’Ï€ijÏ€ij y_{ij}^*=\boldsymbol{x}_{ij}'\boldsymbol{\alpha}^{(s)}+\frac{y_{ij}-\pi_{ij}}{\pi_{ij}}

The IWLS algorithm thus involves the following steps:

  1. Create some suitable starting values for ğ›‘\boldsymbol{\pi}, ğ–\boldsymbol{W}, and ğ²*\boldsymbol{y}^*

  2. Construct the â€œworking dependent variableâ€ ğ²*\boldsymbol{y}^*

  3. Solve the equation

    ğ—â€²ğ–ğ—ğ›‚=ğ—â€²ğ–ğ²* \boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{W}\boldsymbol{X} \boldsymbol{\alpha} = \boldsymbol{X}'\boldsymbol{W}\boldsymbol{y}^*

    for ğ›‚\boldsymbol{\alpha}.

  4. Compute updated ğ›ˆ\boldsymbol{\eta}, ğ›‘\boldsymbol{\pi}, ğ–\boldsymbol{W}, and ğ²*\boldsymbol{y}^*.

  5. Compute the updated value for the log-likelihood or the deviance

    d=2âˆ‘i,jnijlnyijÏ€ij d=2\sum_{i,j}n_{ij}\ln\frac{y_{ij}}{\pi_{ij}}

  6. If the decrease of the deviance (or the increase of the log-likelihood) is smaller than a given tolerance criterian (typically Î”dâ‰¤10âˆ’7\Delta d \leq 10^{-7}) stop the algorighm and declare it as converged. Otherwise go back to step 2 with the updated value of ğ›‚\boldsymbol{\alpha}.

The starting values for the algorithm used by the mclogit package are constructe as follows:

  1. Set

    Î·ij(0)=ln(nij+12)âˆ’1qiâˆ‘kâˆˆğ’®iln(nij+12) \eta_{ij}^{(0)} = \ln (n_{ij}+\tfrac12) - \frac1{q_i}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{S}_i}\ln (n_{ij}+\tfrac12)

    (where qiq_i is the size of the choice set ğ’®i\mathcal{S}_i)

  2. Compute the starting values of the choice probabilities Ï€ij(0)\pi_{ij}^{(0)} according to the equation at the beginning of the page

  3. Compute intial values of the working dependent variable according to

    yij*(0)=Î·ij(0)+yijâˆ’Ï€ij(0)Ï€ij(0) y_{ij}^{*(0)} = \eta_{ij}^{(0)}+\frac{y_{ij}-\pi_{ij}^{(0)}}{\pi_{ij}^{(0)}}
